content:
Interesting Issue: https://www.drupal.org/project/drupal/issues/3132897 (the discussion on groups.drupal .org linked there is also interesting)

But I suspect, even if D7 lives a little longer (LTS or Classic), it will still be the ugly and unloved child, competing with a favored younger brother.
These statistics are really speaking: https://www.drupal.org/project/usage/drupal
450 sites still running Drupal 5! Wow :surprise:

"The community will come together and make this happen."

Based on my observations over the last few years, I doubt that "the community" will come together to actually support anything other than the "latest and greatest."
it could even be construed as irresponsible if they started to support D7/classic as some companies have made a significant investment in LTS

Also, what has baffled me over the last couple of months of looking for work is how few people out there are looking for anyone to help with maintaining any of those 700k+ D7 sites. The overwhelming majority of people looking for Drupal developers want D8 developers.
yeah; my guess is many of the D7 sites are either unmaintained or minimally maintained
That certainly wouldn't surprise me.

Hmm, from that g.d.o discussion:

"Merge every compatible piece of Backdrop into Drupal Classic, and continue active development."
Ah, which was actually copied from https://www.drupal.org/project/d7lts/issues/2999153#comment-12938440

Not all of those 731,190 sites currently using D7 can be unmaintained. :wink: And I don't see much movement from D7 to D8 - for obvious reasons. Several comments in the groups.drupal thread describe exactly why. Very likely many of those D7 will stay D7 and probably die one day as D7.

But I see a realistic chance that some of those people will switch to Backdrop. Maybe they keep their D7s as-is, but create new projects in Backdrop - in the hope for better major upgrade handling. Drupal has proven to do a horrible job regarding that.
I'm still questioning what proportion of those 731,190 sites' owners know Backdrop exists.
it's a great question ... the only thing i've heard so far to increase awareness is adverts ( i mean above and beyond what we already do)
I havent done adverts. How much would a campaign that would be expected to reasonably/significantly raise awareness of the existence of Backdrop likely cost?
I wonder if Drupal would let us add a patch to D7 core that shows a message about D7 EOL and mentions Backdrop...? :wink:

Have a look here: https://backdrop.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/218635-Backdrop/topic/Outreach/near/198753771

We try to get higher in the list of alternatives https://alternativeto.net/software/drupal/ (currently waaaay to low)
Backdrop could pay for adverts on d.o: https://www.drupal.org/association/advertising

Regarding movement in web cms market: if we only could grab a small part of those who currently migrate from Drupal to Wordpress...

https://w3techs.com/technologies/changes/cm-drupal

Which is again a problem of visibility, i guess...

https://w3techs.com/technologies/changes/cm-backdropcms
Blogging beats ads.
I think we can get a lot more awareness by blogging. And it should be useful information like how to upgrade. I should do it myself though. When I've got time hopefully soon
still curious about average costs tho. anyone care to advise roughly? and if blogging is better, what about paying for content?

Blogging can beat ads, depdends on many parameters, but we are far away from having regular blog posts that could outperform GoogleAds in any way. I do support many customers in GoogleAds (together with partners, I am far away from being a pro) but one thing I can tell for sure, competitors are well aware that D7 is EOL next year.
My clients are getting cold calls from agencies telling them their Drupal 7 site is EOL and that they're offering to do it for them
And I think the approach is working for them
do what for them?
Upgrade to Drupal 8
Catching up on and enjoying/appreciating this conversation. :)
My shop evangelizes about Backdrop in every forum we get, which is mostly in nonprofit tech spaces and within our existing client pool (plus anyone who comes to us looking to upgrade to D8)

Still hard to argue against folks' "But I already know WordPress" arguments if they don't really like their D7 site, but otherwise we're having pretty good success lining folks up for the switch to Backdrop. That's all based on an existing relationship though -- it's a much harder sell for new clients!
Yeah, that's how it's with us too
